arm_group.description: CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure) compliant patients
patients who did not use CPAP therapy

brief_summary.textblock:
Positive airway pressure (PAP) therapy is generally offered to patients with obstructive
      sleep apnea. The investigators suggest that beneficial effects of PAP therapy is by
      preventing apneas and therefore reducing cardiac and pulmonary morbidities. The
      investigators sought to verify this by assessing cardiac and pulmonary function during
      exercise.

clinical_study.brief_title: PAP Therapy Sleep Apnea and Exercise

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  obstructive sleep apnea diagnosed by polysomnography

          -  CPAP therapy indicated

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  obstructive or restrictive lung disease

          -  cardiac failure

          -  acute coronary syndrome

          -  inability to cycle

study_pop.textblock:
All consecutive patients newly diasgnosed with obstructive sleep apnea in whom CPAP
        therapy was indicated

facility.name: University of Gaziantep, Faculty of Medicine, Dept. of Pulmonary Diseases

clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Positive Airway Pressure Therapy on Exercise Parameters in Obstructive Sleep Apnea

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: ventilatory equivalent for carbon dioxide at anaerobic threshold

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective
